J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 285.10, up 5.4 (+1.93%), High: 287.60, Low: 282.60, Volume: 4.39m
11:19 am
BE

Which is on the back of Credit Suisse

BE

Negative on the sector, but calls Sainsbury buying Argos "inspired"

BE

A view I have some sympathy for, though up to now I thought I was alone.

11:20 am
BE

Sainsbury wants to acquire a declining business and integrate it into its own
declining business, expecting that the potential synergies will help both. But the crux of the deal rests on reversing the negative, industry-wide real estate problem by eliminating
costly real estate (Argos) while simultaneously reviving unproductive space (Sainsbury).

BE

As for the sector though, here's the exec sum.

BE

Since the start of the year, share prices of UK food retailers have enjoyed a significant
recovery. Tesco has risen by 27%, Sainsbury by 7% and Morrisons by 36%, materially
outpacing the broader market's -2% return.
There is strong motivation towards being more positive – both consensus and recent
market movements are already there, and short positions are still very high, which may
stimulate further share price rises. And investors like a good turnaround story. But the
data do not support a materially better outlook. Retail space – the key driver of market
share – continues to grow at a much faster rate than the overall market, implying lower
average sales densities across the sector. Prices continue to fall, while costs continue to
rise. And the online channel, which is lossmaking for virtually everyone, continues to grow
at double-digit rates.
We hear plenty of reasons why we should be more optimistic. Much of it has to do with the
Discounters, with the view that their sales densities are no longer rising and lower prices
elsewhere will reduce shoppers' incentive to switch. Together, these factors may give the
Discounters a reason to slow down their expansion plans. We think not. Our forecasts are
not reliant on the Discounters growing like-for-like sales and the price gap does not seem
to have closed at all. We do not expect any changes to their store rollout plans.
While suppliers are lowering prices, it is clear that this is not generating higher margins at
retail. We believe competition is savings to be passed along to consumers, which is a
corollary to the inflation / deflation debate: Who benefits when the components of gross
margin change? We do not view food price deflation as a mix of macroeconomic effects,
such as f/x rates or trade sanctions, but rather the microeconomic effect of competition.
Other arguments, such as the significant operational improvements that come from
narrower ranges and better store operations clearly do help profitability, and we already
incorporate those factors into our models. Online is a differentiator, and provides some
element of loyalty, but the cost of fulfilment is very high, as we discussed in our recent
note on online economics.
The main event in grocery is, ironically, non-food. Non-food is the primary reason why we
increase our target price for Sainsbury, to 290p from 240p and upgrade our rating to
Outperform from Underperform. The impending acquisition of Home Retail Group is an
excellent deal, in our view. The structural decline in the core grocery businesses remain
unchanged, and we leave all other target prices as they were.

11:21 am
BE

And from a Sainsbury view specifically ..........

BE

■ A transformative transaction: We expect the acquisition of Home Retail to
boost profits, provide opportunities to grow sales, reduce costs, expand its
customer base and improve logistics. Our pro forma Underlying EPS for
FY18, '19 and '20 change by 0%, +6% and +19%, respectively. We upgrade
our rating to Outperform and increase our price target to 290p from 240p.
■ An immediate solution to space issues: While the transaction will
consume significant amount of management time, we believe it will be time
well spent. Executed successfully, the transaction should allow Sainsbury to
maintain the relevance of its store estate – its biggest asset – for longer.
Sainsbury has stated that 6% of its space (~1.5m ft2) is unproductive and this
transaction addresses this problem immediately.
■ Financing magic: A significant part of the appeal of the transaction is the
creative and symbiotic method of financing it. Argos has a large loan book;
Sainsbury has a bank that is ideally suited to buying such an asset. By using
its bank, Sainsbury effectively monetises that asset, while leverage falls.
■ Our structurally negative view of the sector remains: Sainsbury's actions
are partly in response to the same issues that drive our negative thesis on the
sector: shifting consumer behaviour, the rapid growth of new channels and
the decline of traditional supermarkets. As we have said previously, we do
not expect (or need) Sainsbury to morph into Amazon or Ocado – it just has
to stay ahead of Tesco and Asda.
■ Valuation: We make some minor changes to our stand-alone valuation of
Sainsbury, and we add 46p/share to account for our valuation of the Home
Retail acquisition. Our TP increases to 290p/share and we upgrade our rating
to Outperform from Underperform.

BE

So that's that.

11:26 am
BE

This is a better than feared update in the General Merchandise business
with LFL sales slightly ahead of consensus (albeit forecasts had lowered
ahead of the release). FY16 gross margin guidance is now expected to be
at the top of the previously guided range, in-line with consensus. M&S has
flagged that in January it sharpened its prices on some entry price point
lines and we think further investment in headline price is likely. This could
put pressure on the opportunity for gross margin gains in FY17, but
ultimately we believe it is necessary to support the long-run health of the
business. We view this price investment from M&S as having negative
read across to Next. In the M&S Food business underlying LFL sales
(excluding the boost from the timing of Easter) fell into negative territory
for the first time since 2010. Whilst the Food business continues to
outperform the wider market, this could raise concerns. The stock is
trading on a CY16 PE of 11.7x, broadly in line with Next. We do not
expect consensus forecasts to change following this update.

PM

Does M&S really deserve to be on the same rating as Next?

BE

Does Next deserve to be on the same rating as M&S?

11:28 am
PM

A new energy & focus upon front-end delivery
Given Steve Rowe’s nature - dynamic, active and to the point - we anticipate that M&S will enter a period of further change albeit second guessing the nature and extent of the change under him is difficult. Whilst he has been in the ‘designate’ seat for a few months, a fuller update is to be provided, as may reasonably expected, at the group’s preliminary results on the 25th May. We do, however, expect the prime focus of attention to be on the front end delivery, particularly of aforementioned UK GM, so the ranges, the merchandising, the web-site and store estate. Mr. Rowe spoke on the call of the need to be ‘closer to customers’, a process driven by more data (e.g. SPARKS, which has 4m members), more listening, more visits…he spent his first day at the M&S store in Croydon.

PM

Whilst not necessarily insurmountable, fixing M&S’ GM conundrum, notably sustained brand corrosion, will not be an easy or quick process in our view. If it was not the case then we assert that it would have been done so before now. The solutions somewhat obviously revolve around product, range (including width), merchandising, marketing and price. We struggle to see this process of change involving a mere ‘Elastoplast’ and so some surgery may feature when the time comes to update the market on M&S’ next chapter for development. In doing so, we reiterate the hard and beneficial yards under Mr. Bolland in terms of systems and processes, which means Mr. Rowe inherits control of a business that has sound solvency ratios; FY2016 we forecast net debt (ND) of c£2.1bn making for a ND/EBITDA ratio of 1.6 times (x), which we deem to be sound. As such a platform is in place to make the tills ring more often.

PM

He really likes this Rowe chap

11:29 am
PM

The shares enter the doldrums but we back Rowe

PM

In the near-term M&S from a financial perspective may be on a course to go a little backwards in order to go forwards depending upon Mr. Rowe’s prognosis for the business. However, whilst it is only an act of faith to some degree, he is an executive that we are minded to back, one with the commitment, energy and insight to demonstrably take M&S on a better course, something for which long-standing shareholders’ pine.

It may be expedient for us to reappraise our positive recommendation on the group’s share in light of current uncertainties, we cannot rule out amendments to future year profit expectations at this juncture. Whilst so, we are minded to look through the next few quarters and sustain our backing for Mr. Rowe’s capabilities by sustaining our BUY recommendation on the M&S shares.

11:32 am
BE

Equity values jumping the gun — The FTSE Mining 350 Index is up 17% YTD and has been one of the best-performing sectors so far. We believe part of this can be explained by the severe underweight positions at the end of last year, an improvement in the Chinese economic outlook and the miners delivering on restructuring plans.
What it means for relative valuation — On a relative basis, sector PEs are at a 20-year high vs. the market, we see UK mining’s absolute 12-month fwd P/E at ~25x (nearly an all-time high since 2000) and we see the sector P/E relative to the FTSE 100 at ~1.5x, making it look relatively overbought compared with its 0.8x historical average. Part of the explanation is the low earnings base of the miners and arguably the miners have tracked EV/EBITDA more closely.
Commodities basket reasonably neutral — Commodities have been a mixed bag since the beginning of the year, with iron ore and Brent up 26% and 4%, respectively, while the base metals block is slightly weaker. Overall, the Bloomberg Commodity Index has remained flat so far this year (Figure 6). So, arguably, most of the performance this year has been driven by sentiment rather by a major shift in underlying fundamentals.
Too much and too soon — Where to from here? We still think the sector is due for a pull-back, with short-term valuations becoming stretched. This is one of the reasons we downgraded the sector to neutral in our note Metals & Mining - Top Down and Bottom Up: Taking Sector Down to Neutral. We are also cautious on the short-term outlook for Industrial Metals — Too Much Too Soon (For Prices)?; we caution against chasing any further short-term commodities moves on the upside and expect the trajectory of base metals to diverge in the coming weeks as specific structural themes take precedence over prices. This is likely to moderate the equities’ performance going into next quarter, in our view.

11:35 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,297, up 39 (+0.92%), High: 4,330, Low: 4,274, Volume: 713.22k
BE

Today it gets put back onto Exane's M&A target list.

BE

We are adding Shire (again)
We have been in and out of Shire over the years. So far we have always made money although Shire still remains magnificently independent and has little desire to be subsumed into a larger group. Nevertheless management recommended the Abbvie bid, showing that they will not let corporate ambition stand in the way of an exceptional opportunity to create value for shareholders. In the end only a change to the US tax inversion rules scuppered the deal. After the recent change to administrative guidance on tax inversion it looks as if large tax driven deals are off the menu.

Up to 40% off
But Big Pharma in general has other reasons than tax efficiency to make big acquisitions. Pfizer, for instance, has a market cap of USD200bn and just USD10bn of net debt. Declining margins and patent expiries have only been offset by massive share buybacks. (Pfizer has bought back 25% of its own shares since 2009). But buying back shares is not a long term business model. Big pharma needs two things - medium term organic growth and a more efficient balance sheet. A debt funded purchase of Shire, pre or post a Baxalta deal, offers a solution to both problems at a bargain basement price. Shire shares are down by 30% versus their 5,800p peak last summer. Sterling has fallen by 10% against the dollar over the same period.

What's not to like?
No doubt Shire could dodge the M&A bullet once more. But not to worry. Due in no small part to the technical impact of Shire's own bid for Baxalta the stock has become very cheap (to such an extent that it is the first Pharma stock we have ever been able to include in our Deep Value list). On a standalone basis Shire trades on a P/E of 13.5x 2016e and 11.2x 2017e for 14% organic sales growth and 20% plus earnings growth in both years. On a proforma basis, Shire/Baxalta trades on 9.5x 2017 earnings, a 45% discount to EU large pharma peers. Shire/Baxalta is trading at 0.74x EV/NPV. Deal or no deal, we think we will make money.

11:47 am
BE

The “miss” (at least versus our estimates) was mostly cost-driven, as
instructional and student advisory and G&A costs were higher than thought.
Nevertheless, y/y declines in both starts and enrollment trends worsened;
management blamed much of this (in the press release; no earnings call was
held) on its transformation plan which reduced the number of associate
programs and the frequency of start dates, among other items. Management also
cited the pending merger and the “challenges in accurately forecasting operating
results” during Univ. of Phoenix’s transformational plan as reasons for
withdrawing guidance. No update was provided re: the pending transaction; we
believe the next key milestone will be the shareholder Special Meeting to
approve the merger slated for April 28, 2016. We acknowledge the risks of this
transaction not occurring -- something the market appears to be speculating
given the wide spread versus the proposed $9.50 takeout price. We are reducing
our EPS estimates as follows: F3Q16 to $0.23 from $0.34; F2016 to $0.11 from
$0.55 and F2017 to $0.08 from $0.49.

BE

And Deutsche on the market it's in.

BE

New enrollment in the February quarter was down 39% YoY versus our -38%
expectation and -38% last quarter. The comp was 8pts easier so the 2-year
stacked comp worsened to -52%. With no conference call and guidance
withdrawn, we assume trends could get worse from here before they get
better. Total enrollment was -24% in the quarter to 162,400 versus our -25%
expectation and -22% in the previous quarter. Persistence was up slightly YoY
(after being down for at least five straight quarters) versus our flat expectation.
With over 100,000 fewer students enrolled today than versus 10 quarters ago
(65,000 fewer than 6-qtrs ago), we would expect to see more improvement in
persistence if this transformation plan is having any success. Due to the $9.50
per share private equity takeover bid for the company, weaker than expected
results, and operational transformation plan, management has withdrawn
guidance for FY16. Based on their press release commentary, mgmt would
have had to lower guidance after these results. We continue to assume that
the deal should close, as we believe management likely gave themselves
enough cushion to hit the undisclosed operational & financial targets required
to close the deal.

11:48 am
BE

BE

11:49 am
BE

US Higher Education is our biggest single area of concern with Pearson

Our biggest area of structural concern with Pearson is its US higher education business, which we estimate is at least a third of group profits: with for-profits structurally impacted and community college enrolments also down in 2016 (for profits and community colleges in combination made up c. half of US higher education enrolment growth from 2000-9), enrolment issues are compounding PSON's structural problems with students buying fewer expensive high-margin textbooks.

Our top Sell in the sector

We see Pearson as the most structurally challenged of the stocks that we cover relative to its rating. Not only does it face structural headwinds in its US higher education business, but it is also facing significant headwinds in its US testing business; weakness in its designated Core markets such as the UK; and no top-line growth in its so-called “Growth” markets. The fact that Pearson wrote down c. 15% of its entire intangible / goodwill asset base is an implicit (or even explicit) sign that management havew downgraded longer-term growth forecasts for the business. These structural pressures make it all the harder moving forwards for the company to sustain its dividend.

BE

Our 450p DCF driven target price is based on a terminal growth rate of -1.8% and a WACC of 9%.

11:51 am

BE

BE

11:51 am
BE

(Ditto.)

BE

Not really taking a view on the possibility of a bid, though.

BE

While we regard Fidessa as a high quality, differentiated business, we believe the
difficulties faced in its end markets along with the uncertain threat to its customers
from the upcoming UK referendum on EU membership (June 23), are not currently
being adequately priced in by investors. With the shares up 22% in Q1 (vs FTSE250
down 3%) and now trading at 29x P/E (2016E), a 30% premium to its own 10-year
average and close to its pre-crisis peak multiple (34x), we downgrade to Sell.

11:52 am
BE

For global investment banks, UBS forecasts FICC to be down 26% y/y in Q1, Equities
down 10%, and IBD down 15%. Fidessa derives 93% of its revenue from investment
banks and brokerages. The June EU membership referendum in the UK adds to the
uncertainty, possibly delaying business decisions made by Fidessa's customers, c40% of
whom are based in Europe (mostly in the UK). In our recent CIO Survey, over 20% of
UK respondents indicated that they might defer spending due to the potential for
Brexit. In the event of Brexit, there is potential for large-scale disruption to customers.
We remain conservative and exclude these potential downside risks from our numbers
yet still arrive at a Sell rating.

BE

The elephant in the room with Fidessa is potential upside risk of a takeover approach,
which has re-surfaced in media reports of late (e.g. the FT on 9th March). Nonetheless,
we note that at 29x P/E, Fidessa is approaching its peak multiple over the last ten years
(34x), achieved in January 2007, which we imagine would cool down demand for the
asset. We expect a Q1 IMS release – typically light in detail - at the end of April. We do
not believe it will justify what we perceive as a very high valuation, relative to
history/peers.

BE

With Fidessa now at the top end of its 52-week trading range, we downgrade to Sell.
Our price target is based on a blend of a DCF model (WACC=7.1%, g=2%) and 22x
2017E P/E, in-line with Fidessa's own 10-year historic average multiple. Higher EPS
estimates due to ú weakening push up our PT.

11:56 am
BE

lybe has confirmed that FY16E results will be in line with market expectations.
This, in our view, reflects encouraging progress in the company’s turnaround
and firm evidence of improved resilience and management controls in difficult
market conditions driven by unwelcome extraneous events. Flybe reports that for
FY17E, “summer trading is on track with the additional capacity selling through
as planned” although “in view of ongoing macro-economic uncertainty, Flybe has
now hedged both fuel oil and US dollar to 90% of 2016/17’s exposure. The rise in the
value of the dollar (annual spend c.$315m) since the turn of the year has impacted
2016/17’s operating costs by £7m.” We have adjusted FY17E PBT accordingly.
● 4Q16 trading: Flybe reports stable yields against a 2.4% y-o-y increase in capacity
with load factor of 68% (down 2 ppts y-o-y). Passenger revenues were, therefore, in
line with the prior year. The robust response of the company to a deteriorating demand
environment in Q4 (following the Paris bombings) highlights the greater resilience of
the business and improved management controls, in our view.

BE

● Summer 2016: There is a c.17% increase in capacity y-o-y, half of which relates to
E195s deployed in airport partnership deals. Around 21% of capacity is sold, 3ppts
behind y-o-y. New capacity is focused either on routes where partners provide cost
mitigation or on routes which adhere to the strengths of the business model: those with
additional frequency requirements, or new low volume, short-hop regional routes. Unit
cost reduction remains a relentless focus, providing margin resilience. Management
says it is reviewing the capacity growth rate beyond the summer.
● Aircraft acquisition: In March 2016, Flybe bought three Q400 aircraft, previously on
operating leases, for $34m cash. This is in line with Flybe’s strategy of rebalancing
its aircraft fleet towards ownership. There is a cost saving we estimate of c.£250k per
aircraft. The cash position remains strong with total cash of £181.3m.
● Outlook: CEO Saad Hammad says, “Our booking profile for the summer reflects our
capacity investments and our growing appeal to business travellers who typically book
as close as possible to their day of travel. We look forward to making further progress
over the coming year as we enter the next chapter of our journey which is focused on
disciplined and profitable growth.”

11:57 am
BE

Flybe has confirmed the year to March 2016E has finished in line with expectations. This has come despite a difficult trading environment and slower bookings after the Paris attacks in November. Management's swift move to scale back capacity growth in Q4 appears to have successfully defended the bottom line. However, dollar strength is a headwind for March 2017E and 2018E, despite hedging, and we have cut our forecasts by up to 26% to reflect this. The cut to estimates is disappointing, but mitigated by a better cash performance. We cut our target price to 105p from 120p but retain our BUY recommendation.

The Company was pleased to announce today that it has identified an opportunity to acquire interests in various gold exploration properties in Mali and Côte d'Ivoire (the "West African Exploration Projects") that are currently owned by Taruga Gold Limited ("Taruga"), an Australian Securities Exchange ("ASX") listed company. Taruga's interests in the West African Exploration Projects are held through a wholly-owned subsidiary, International Goldfields (Bermuda) Limited ("IGS"). The Company is proposing to acquire 100 per cent. of the issued share capital of IGS for a consideration of £410,000 to be satisfied through the issue of 1,025,000,000 new Ordinary Shares (the "Consideration Shares") to Taruga (the "Acquisition").
